author: Carron Muleya
content:
Getting started with programming

Coding is the process of writing out steps for a computer to follow to achieve a goal or perform a task. Typically, coding is done using a programming language -- like Java or Python or C , which the coder uses to translate his or her ideas into words, phrases, and syntax that the computer understands. These instructions are also called "commands." Coding is typically done as one critical step in the larger process of computer programming. Computer programming involves identifying a problem or challenge, considering potential solutions, writing code that can enact those solutions, and then testing and revising the code to achieve the desired results.

Computer programs, also called "apps," can generally be run on a wide range of machines and devices, including computers, laptops, tablets, gaming consoles, and more. They include everything from operating systems, like iOS, Windows, or Android, to robust applications like Office or Photoshop, to web-based programs like Netflix or Instagram, to games like Minecraft or Candy Crush. Everything that a computer or device does is through a program.

Why learning Programming

Coding isn't just for "techies" or kids who want to work on computers. There are lots of compelling reasons for all students to learn to code.

First, it teaches students how to be digital creators -- to create their own websites, apps, and programs. Coding allows students to wield the full power of the internet -- and multimedia -- to share their ideas, talents, and creativity with the world. Coding also provides students with skills that apply across content areas. By learning to tell machines what to do, students engage in problem-solving and computational thinking, which apply to academic and professional disciplines across the board For example, consider heavily used platforms like Instagram or Amazon. These platforms use algorithms, which are coded formulas, designed to get users to use the platform as much as possible. Knowing that these platforms are coded this way helps students understand the larger ramifications of their use: The platform is able to collect more and more data, and there is potential for overuse and for being manipulated into using the platform more than is healthy.

Coding can also be lots of fun and provide students with a creative outlet, and it will give them a leg up when they begin pursuing a career and other professional goals.

"Most people won't grow up to become professional computer scientists or programmers, but those skills of thinking creatively, reasoning systematically, working collaboratively â€¦ are things that people can use no matter what they're doing in their work lives."

What you need to know before coding

The short answer is, nothing. No formal prerequisites or specific skills need to be mastered before kids get started. Coding, does, however, challenge students to use their existing knowledge and skills in several areas, including:

Basic computer skills. Students will need to know or learn fundamental skills for using a device, including clicking, typing, logging in and out, etc. Logic. Coding challenges students to: identify cause and effect, sequence, make inferences, and perform other cognitive skills. Perseverance. Coding requires students to experiment and use trial and error to figure out which commands, syntax, and sequencing will lead to the outcome(s) they desire. This requires a certain level of stick-to-itiveness that can be challenging for learners of all ages. Attention to detail. Sometimes the smallest of details can cause coding syntax to error out or to not function as desired. Students will need to apply or learn mindfulness and patience when reading and writing their code.

What resources are good for learning programming


The trending technology is rapidly changing. In which teachers won't give full potential to teach you what real is taking place out there in these days. This is because most of them learnt so many year ago. Mayb even before python gets in this world therefore to keep yourself updated it's good to use different sources for learning programming and some technologies. Approaching coding in this way -- as a tool for navigating the digital world -- helps students make use of their existing knowledge, experiences, and values in the learning process. It supports them in making coding projects that are actionable and applicable to the real world There are lots of great apps out there for teaching coding, and the landscape is changing rapidly.

title: Home! Chatsfly

author: Carron Muleya
content:
Who we are

Our website address is: https://agrofarm.co.zw/

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitorâ€™s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymised string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service Privacy Policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognise and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

author: Carron Muleya
content:
Getting started with Java

JAVA was developed by Sun Microsystems Inc in 1991, later acquired by Oracle Corporation. It was developed by James Gosling and Patrick Naughton. It is a simple programming language. Writing, compiling and debugging a program is easy in java. It helps to create modular programs and reusable code.

Java terminology

Before we start learning Java, lets get familiar with common java terms.

Java Virtual Machine (JVM)

This is generally referred as JVM. Before, we discuss about JVM lets see the phases of program execution. Phases are as follows: we write the program, then we compile the program and at last we run the program.
  1. Writing of the program is of course done by java programmer like you and me.
  2. Compilation of program is done by javac compiler, javac is the primary java compiler included in java development kit (JDK). It takes java program as input and generates java bytecode as output.
  3. In third phase, JVM executes the bytecode generated by compiler. This is called program run phase.
So, now that we understood that the primary function of JVM is to execute the bytecode produced by compiler. Each operating system has different JVM, however the output they produce after execution of bytecode is same across all operating systems. That is why we call java as platform independent language.

Bytecode

As discussed above, javac compiler of JDK compiles the java source code into bytecode so that it can be executed by JVM. The bytecode is saved in a .class file by compiler.

Java Development Kit(JDK)

While explaining JVM and bytecode, I have used the term JDK. Letâ€™s discuss about it. As the name suggests this is complete java development kit that includes JRE (Java Runtime Environment), compilers and various tools like JavaDoc, Java debugger etc. In order to create, compile and run Java program you would need JDK installed on your computer.

Java Runtime Environment(JRE)

JRE is a part of JDK which means that JDK includes JRE. When you have JRE installed on your system, you can run a java program however you wonâ€™t be able to compile it. JRE includes JVM, browser plugins and applets support. When you only need to run a java program on your computer, you would only need JRE. These are the basic java terms that confuses beginners in java. For complete java glossary refer this link: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/information/glossary.html

Main Features of JAVA

Java is a platform independent language Compiler(javac) converts source code (.java file) to the byte code(.class file). As mentioned above, JVM executes the bytecode produced by compiler. This byte code can run on any platform such as Windows, Linux, Mac OS etc. Which means a program that is compiled on windows can run on Linux and vice-versa. Each operating system has different JVM, however the output they produce after execution of bytecode is same across all operating systems. That is why we call java as platform independent language.

Java is an Object Oriented language

Object oriented programming is a way of organizing programs as collection of objects, each of which represents an instance of a class.

4 main concepts of Object Oriented programming are:
  1. Abstraction
  2. Encapsulation
  3. Inheritance
  4. Polymorphism
  5. Simple

Java is considered as one of simple language because it does not have complex features like Operator overloading, Multiple inheritance, pointers and Explicit memory allocation.

Robust Language

Robust means reliable. Java programming language is developed in a way that puts a lot of emphasis on early checking for possible errors, thatâ€™s why java compiler is able to detect errors that are not easy to detect in other programming languages. The main features of java that makes it robust are garbage collection, Exception Handling and memory allocation.

Secure

We donâ€™t have pointers and we cannot access out of bound arrays (you get ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if you try to do so) in java. Thatâ€™s why several security flaws like stack corruption or buffer overflow is impossible to exploit in Java.

Java is distributed

Using java programming language we can create distributed applications. RMI(Remote Method Invocation) and EJB(Enterprise Java Beans) are used for creating distributed applications in java. In simple words: The java programs can be distributed on more than one systems that are connected to each other using internet connection. Objects on one JVM (java virtual machine) can execute procedures on a remote JVM.

Multithreading

Java supports multithreading. Multithreading is a Java feature that allows concurrent execution of two or more parts of a program for maximum utilisation of CPU.

Portable

As discussed above, java code that is written on one machine can run on another machine. The platform independent byte code can be carried to any platform for execution that makes java code portable.
description: Understanding history of java programming languages and more of its terms
title: Getting started with Java

author: Carron Muleya
content:
Variables in Java

Variables are containers for storing data values. In other words, a variable is a name which is associated with a value that can be changed. For example when I write int a=10; here variable name is a, which is associated with value 10,int is a data type which represents that this variable holds integer values. We will cover the data types in the next topics. Here we will discuss about variables.

How to Declare(create) a variable in Java

To create a variable, you must specify the type and assign it a value. Below is the syntax to create and assign value to a variable.
data_type name= value;

Where data_type is one of the data types that would be discussed in the next article, name is the name of the variable , the equal sign(=) is an operator(we will discuss later about this) and value is anything for example number, word, letter etc.We call these data right.
See this example.
int num=10; Here num is a variable ,int is a data type and 10 is the value. We will discuss the data type in next article so do not worry too much about it, just understand that int data type allows this num variable to hold integer values. You can also declare a variable only without giving it a value such that you will assign a value later ..see below int num; Then to assign a variable above you can just say num=10;

Variables naming convention in java There are certain things that you need to know when naming a variable. 1) Variables naming cannot contain white spaces, for example: int first num = 100; This is invalid because the variable name has space in it. 2) Variable name can begin with special characters such as $ and _ 3) As per the java coding standards the variable name should begin with a lower case letter, for example int number; For lengthy variables names that has more than one words do it like this: int smallNumber; int bigNumber; (start the second word with capital letter).It is not a harm to start with uppercase but as practice we encourage you to follow the above. 4) Variable names are case sensitive in Java.For example the name Number is not same as number. 5)Reserved words (like Java keywords, such as int or boolean) cannot be used as names
Types of Variables
There are three types of variables in Java: static variable instance variable local variable Static (or class) Variable Static variables are also known as class variable because they are associated with the class and common for all the instances of class.
Example of static variable

public class StaticVarExample {
   public static String myClassVar="class or static variable";
	
   public static void main(String args[]){
      StaticVarExample obj = new StaticVarExample();
      
      //Displaying static variables  "class or static variable"
      System.out.println(obj.myClassVar);
      


      //changing the value of static variable
      obj2.myClassVar = "Changed Text";

      //displaying the static variable  "Changed Text"
      System.out.println(obj.myClassVar);
   }
}
Output:
class or static variable Changed Text As you can see the value at the first is the one inside the class but outside the method and last output is the one inside the method only. This show us how to modify a static variable in java.
Instance variable
A variable declared inside the class but outside the body of the method, is called instance variable. It is not declared as static. It is called instance variable because its value is instance specific and is not shared among instances.
Example of Instance variable

public class InstanceVarExample {
   String myInstanceVar="instance variable";
	
   public static void main(String args[]){
	InstanceVarExample obj = new InstanceVarExample();
	InstanceVarExample obj2 = new InstanceVarExample();
	InstanceVarExample obj3 = new InstanceVarExample();
		
	System.out.println(obj.myInstanceVar);
	System.out.println(obj2.myInstanceVar);
	System.out.println(obj3.myInstanceVar);

		
	obj2.myInstanceVar = "Changed Text";

		
	System.out.println(obj.myInstanceVar);
	System.out.println(obj2.myInstanceVar);
	System.out.println(obj3.myInstanceVar);
   }
}
Output:
instance variable instance variable instance variable instance variable Changed Text instance variable
Local Variable
A variable declared inside the body of the method is called local variable. You can use this variable only within that method and the other methods in the class aren't even aware that the variable exists. A local variable cannot be defined with "static" keyword.
Example of Local variable

public class VariableExample {
   // instance variable
   public String var1="instance variable";
    
   public void myMethod(){
    	// local variable
    	String var= "Inside Method";
    	System.out.println(var);
   }
   public static void main(String args[]){
      // Creating object
      VariableExample obj = new VariableExample();
    	
      /* We are calling the method, that changes the 
       * value of myVar. We are displaying var1 again after 
       * the method call, to demonstrate that the local 
       * variable scope is limited to the method itself.
       */
      System.out.println("Calling Method");
      obj.myMethod();
      System.out.println(obj.var);
   }
}
Output:
Calling Method Inside Method instance variable If you try to access a local variable in another method, the compiler with throw an error. This is because a local variable is only accessed and used by the method that it is created inside it.
For example

public class localVar{
     public static void main(String args[]){
         localVar obj=localVar();
         String var=obj.name;
        System.out.print(var);
   }
  public void printName(){
     String name="Chatsfly";
 }

}
The above will give an error because you are trying to print the variable with name var which is on the other method.
Example to understand the all types of variables in java

class A{  
int data=50;//instance variable  
static int m=100;//static variable  
void method(){  
int n=90;//local variable  
}  
}//end of class
description: Understanding how variables work in java programming language
title: Variables in java

author: Carron Muleya
content:
Test problems to be done in C programming Language

Please attend all these questions, you can try to set your own time frame complete these problems. Recommended time frame: 2hours

  1. Write a program to sort elements of an array
  2. Give the four data types in C and show how they are declared
  3. Write a C program that converts decimal numbers to binary.
  4. The wind chill index (WCI) is calculated from the wind speed v in miles per hour and the temperature t in Fahrenheit. Three formulas are used, depending on the wind speed:
    if (0 <= v <= 4) then WCI = t
    if (v >=45) then WCI = 1.6t - 55
    otherwise, WCI = 91.4 + (91.4 - t)(0.0203v - 0.304(v)1/2 - 0.474). Write a program that can calculate the wind chill index.
  5. Rewrite the C program below using a for loop statement 
    
#include <stdio.h>
int main()
{
    int i = 10;
    do{
        printf("Hello %d\n", i );
        i = i -1;
    }while ( i > 0 );

    getch();
return 0;
}
  6. Write a program that reads an integer and checks whether it is odd or even. Show the algorithm for this program using a flow chart. For example:
    Enter a number: 25
    25 is an odd number.
  7. Write a C program to calculate the area of a circle and the circumference of a circle, based on a radius given by a user.
  8. Write a C program that calculates n! where n is a number entered at the keyboard, e.i write a program to calculate a factorial of a number.

author: Carron Muleya
content:
Understanding git and Github

Through this post I will help you understand the two platforms git and github,their difference and what are they used for. In this post am not real focused on showing you git commands and more deep stuff, and therefore if you are interested on understanding git commands you should visit this post.

Table of content

  1. Understanding version control
  2. Difference between Git and GitHub
  3. How do Git and GitHub work

Understanding version control

Version Control Systems(VCS) are the software tools for tracking/managing all the changes made to the source code during the project development. It stores your project(s) and allows you to view all the changes that you have made. What does this mean?, Think when you are developing your projects, their are many changes that you are making, where you are fixing bugs,deleting and updating codes. Sometimes you delete some codes and wish if you can get them back and that is where VCS comes in. A Version Control System allows you to view those codes that you have deleted by letting you see all changes that you have made from the starting point.

Types of Version Control System
  1. Local Version Control System
  2. Centralized Version Control System
  3. Distributed Version Control System
Local Version Control System

Local Version Control is the one which is located on your computer. To use a Local Version Control you need to download and install it on your pc. The advantage of Local version control is that you don't always need internet in order for you to view the changes that you have made. The great disadvantage is that if your machine crashes all your project on Local Version Control will be erased

Centralized Version Control System

Centralized Version Control System is when the projects are put in one server that is accessible to your team. Think about it when your are developing one project with your friends, the good thing is to put the project in a place where your friends can edit it with their own machines.In the Centralized Version Control Systems, there will be a single central server that contains all the files related to the project

You can see that the only drawback of using centralized Version Cotrol is that, if it crashes everything will lost. Sorry if you have been wondering where the word Repository comes in,well this is just a place to store your project e.i I mean your project(s) in Version Control System

Distributed Version Control System

To overcome the problems of the above two, we have Distributed Version Control System which combines those above and make sure that there is also a VCS on your pc and the other(S) accessible to everyone. In a distributed version control system, there will be one or more servers and many collaborators similar to the centralized system. In this case if you have a project that you are doing with others, all the collaborators of that project will have their repository with the exact copy of project that you have.

Difference between Git and GitHub

We have introduced each other to Version Conrol Systems, they is no doubt that these two are examples of Version Control Systems. Yes, Git and Github they are Version Control Systems but they work differently and they are originated from different Companies.

Git is a Local Version Control System which tracks changes of the source codes on your PC. To use Git you need to download and install it to your machine. It can be installed on the most common operating systems like Windows, Mac, and Linux. On the other hand Github is a Centralized Version Control System. It is used to host your source codes through web cloud services. The best thing about github is that even when your PC is at home you can go to your project repository and view/edit the codes. For you to use Github you need to create an account at https://github.com/. Github works with Git whereby you push/update your source codes from your local repository to your github repository(remote repository). However using Git doesn't depend on github.

author: Carron Muleya
content:
String in C

In almost all programming languages there is what we call Strings. In some languages strings are considered as data types, but in C this is not true. In this section we will explore whatever you need to know about string.

Table of Contents
  1. Understanding String
  2. Ways to declare and initialize a String
  3. Ways to read a String

Understanding String

Previously we have talked about characters,recall we said when you want to create characters you do like below. 


char ch='A'; //This is how to declare a character and give it a value;
Think when we want to store a large number of characters, what where we going to use, arrays? Yes arrays are good to store many characters. Arrays will be good but we have another option which is String. A String is a sequence of characters, just like an arrays of characters a string stores a sequence of characters.

Ways to declare and initialize a String

We have two ways that we can use to decalare and initialize a String. Recall a String is a sequence of characters therefore dealing with string will be as easy as dealing with characters and array of characters. Below are ways to create a string

Method 1: String Literal

#include<stdio.h>
int main(){
    char my_string[]="chatsfly"; //String is a sequence of characters. Here is how to create a String
    return 0;
}

In the above example line 4 we have seen how to create a string,the word my_string is a variable name followed by two square brackets [] which means that this is a form of an array. Then the value of this String is chatsfly.
Note: When creating a character we use single quotes,whereas when dealing with String we use double quotes.

Method 2: As an array of characters

#include<stdio.h>
int main(){
    char my_string[]={'c','h','a','t','s','f','l','y','\0'}; //String is a sequence of characters. Here is how to create a String
    return 0;
}

In the above example line 4 we have seen how to create a string,the word my_string is a variable name followed by two square brackets [] which means that this is a form of an array. Because a string is an array of characters we can simply create a String from an array. The value of a variable my_string will be similar to the one on Method 1 which is chatsfly. Please note in the above example there is a character '\0' at the end of the array, this is required when creating a String so as to differentiate it with normal array of characters.

Difference between String literal and Character Array.
  1. When using character array(method 2) we need to add '\0' at the end, while in method1(String literal) we are not.s
  2. We cannot reassing a String Literal to another value while in character array we can.

Ways to print or read values in a String

To print a String you just use a placeholder %s, remember when we want to print an int we use %d and for char its %c. Below is an example to print a String. 


#include<stdio.h>
int main(){
    char my_string1[]={'c','h','a','t','s','f','l','y','\0'}; 
    char my_string2[]="chatsfly"; 
  
    printf("My first string is %s",my_string1); // %s is a placeholder for string
    
    printf("\nMy second string is %s",my_string2); 
    return 0;
}
Output: My first string is chatsfly
My second string is chatsfly
You can see that printing a String is the same weather you used method1 or 2.

Printing a character in a String.

Lets say you have a String and you want to print a character certain position. Just like in arrays to print a character in a string you need to specify it's index. See example below: 


#include<stdio.h>
int main(){
    
    char my_string[]="chatsfly";
    char first_char=my_string[0];  //To store the first character of my_string on variable first_char
    
    printf("\nFirst char is %c",first_char); //To print value of variable first_char

    printf("\nSecond char is %c",my_string[1]); //Print the second character. We didnt store it somewhere here

    printf("\n%c",my_string[2]);// print value at position 3. index 2
    return 0;
}
Output: First char is c
Second char is h
a
Note: To print an element at postion 1 we say my_string[0],wherby 0 means index 0 and if we put 1 it means index 1. Like in array indexes in String starts at 0

Printing elements of a String using a loop.

We can also print characters using a loop(for loop,while loop and etc).Here is an example:


#include<stdio.h>
int main(){
   
    char my_string[]="chatsfly"; 
    int i=0;//start at index 0
    while(my_string[i]!='\0'){ //loop untill we get to the last elements
        printf("%c",my_string[i]);
        i++;
    }
    return 0;
}
Output: chatsfly

Note: The last element of a String in C is '\0'. We have seen this when creating a string in method2, therefore by using a while loop until the last element '\0' we have managed to print all elements of a String

Dealing with String doesn't end here,we didn't talk about taking String input from the user String to read more on String just click button Next
PREVIOUS NEXT

Exercise:

  1. Write a program to print the first and last character of the String My string.
  2. Use a loop to print the elements of the string 123'npP\WVString

author: Carron
content:
Random Test And Questions in C

  1. Write a C program to enter two numbers and find their sum.
  2. Write a C program to enter two angles of a triangle and find the third angle.
  3. Write a C program to enter P, T, R and calculate Simple Interest.
  4. Write a program that prompts the user for any integer between 65 and 90. After the user has entered the value it should give the equivalent character in ASCII. For example if the user enters 65 it should print A and if the user enters 82 it should print R. The program should execute until the user opts not to.
  5. Write a program to read data from a file and count how many words are there?
  6. Write a program to count how many prime numbers are there in an array of integers? Then print those prime numbers
  7. Given the payment schedule below, Write a program that would allow one to calculate how much bonus they supposed to be paid given the number of overtime hours they would have worked and number of hour they have been absent. The program should prompt you to enter as many employees as the user has requested to calculate their bonus.
    8. Bonus Schedule
    Overtime-(2/3)*Absent Bonus paid
    >40 hrs
    > 30 but <= 40 hrs
    > 20 but <= 30 hrs
    > 10 but <= 20 hrs
    < 10hrs
    		 $50
    $40
    $30
    $20
    $10
  8. Write a C program to find HCF (GCD) of two numbers.
  9. Write a C program to find LCM of two numbers.
  10. Write a C program to print Fibonacci series up to n terms.
  11. Write a program to convert number from base 10 to 8. And from base 10 to 2
  12. C Program to convert days to years, weeks and days
  13. C program to find string length
  14. C program to reverse a string enter by user
  15. C Program to count number of alphabets, digits and special characters in string
  16. Write a C program that calculates n! where n is a number entered at the keyboard and n! = n * (n â€“ 1) * (n â€“ 2)*---*4*3*2*1.
  17. C Program to find the largest number among three number.
  18. Write a program to sort elements of an array using selection sort
  19. Write a program to sort elements of an array using bubble sort
  20. Write a program to search for an element from an array using linear search.
  21. Write a program to search for an element from an array using binary search.
